thread.title: Alexandre Lacazette 'psychologically destroyed' by booing
thread.title_full: Alexandre Lacazette 'psychologically destroyed' by booing | Daily Mail Online

author: Oliver Todd for MailOnline
title: Alexandre Lacazette 'psychologically destroyed' by booing
text:
Lyon striker Alexandre Lacazette has been 'psychologically destroyed' after fans greeted his hints at a move away with abuse, according to his club's president.
Jean-Michel Aulas said supporters' conceptions on Lacazette's motives were 'based on a misunderstanding' in a staunch defence of the French forward, who was targeted in Wednesday's 4-0 win over Nancy.
The 25-year-old, who has been targeted by Arsenal and watched by a host of other European big guns, hinted in an interview this week that 'the right moment has arrived to leave'.
Lyon striker Alexandre Lacazette was 'psychologically destroyed' by fans' reactions to him
ALEXANDRE LACAZETTE Age : 25
Position : Striker
Club : Lyon
Appearances this season : 26
Goals : 22
But Aulas is adamant that there has been no 'betrayal' by his top talent in declaring an interest in one day moving on to a bigger club.
Lacazette scored Lyon's second goal from the penalty spot in their 4-0 win over Nancy on Wednesday night and set up Nabil Fekir for the third — but his celebrations were muted.
'Alexandre is destroyed psychologically because of what's happened this evening and it was based on a misunderstanding,' Aulas told reporters .
'Because Alexandre didn't say that he wanted to leave Lyon to go and play for a big club. He was interviewed by one of your colleagues to talk about the derby and in the course of a sentence they said to him "but would you [leave one day]?"
Lyon president Jean-Michel Aulas says Lacazette is struggling after talk of him leaving
'Alexandre hasn't betrayed the club. He simply said that one day if like his friend Sam [Umtiti] he could go play for Barcelona or if like Karim Benzema, who left for Real Madrid and everyone was happy for him, he could go to a big club, he might.'
Aulas was particularly frustrated that the interview was published ahead of Lyon's derby against St Etienne — which they lost — last weekend.
'Why bring that out on the day of a derby?' he said. 'You're putting huge pressure on kids... in front of thousands of people who don't understand. I'm disappointed and it upset me.'
The interview which led to Lacazette's problems saw him tell Canal+ that he might seek a 'change of scenery' in the summer.
The striker scored for Lyon in their 4-0 win over Nancy but looks set for a summer move
'I think that the right moment has arrived to leave,' Lacazette said.
'I think that this summer I will need a change of scenery and discover something else, still with the idea of advancing and progressing in terms of football and as a person.
'I will continue to work, in the hope that good opportunities will come this summer.'
Aulas has said he will not stand in the striker's way if one of Europe's giants come in for him.
